results.title: Carve her name with pride
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Daniel M. Angel and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Based on R.J. Minney’s novel this inspiring true story of war heroine, Violette Szabo, who volunteered to be parachuted into France as a secret agent to re-organise a shattered resistance group. Virginia McKenna gives the performance of her career as the courageous secret agent, and this magnificent film ensures that no-one will forget Violette’s bravery and conviction in what she believed in most - freedom from tyranny. Also stars Paul Scofield, Jack Warner, Denise Grey and Maurice Ronet.

results.title: Carve a Ball and Claw Foot
results.brief_description: Learn how to scale the ball-and-claw to furniture plan, how to machine stock to yield a graceful bandsaw cabriole leg ready for carving, how to lay out form, cut-in with a mallet and gouge and shape the dragon’s claw for a vigorous looking grip, how to carve efficiently, keeping tools sharp as you work.

results.title: Cartouche = Swords of Blood
results.creator_credit: Philippe De Broca, Georges Dancigers, VIDES Cinematografica, Filmsonor and Ariane
results.brief_description: Jean-Paul Belmondo is a good-hearted thief operating in 18th century Paris. He teams up with Venus, a gipsy pickpocket (Claudia Cardinale), overthrows the leader of the pickpocket gang (Marcel Dalio) and turns it into a crime syndicate that gives the fancy baubles of the rich to the poor. “Cartouche” encompasses tragedy, farce and violence in a popular, high-flown adventure.

results.title: Cartoon favourites. - Volume 2
results.brief_description: This tape includes 7 cartoons featuring some of your favourite cartoon characters. Stories include; “Rookie revue”; “Porky’s bear facts”; “Jasper and the haunted house”; “A Bout with a trout”; “Scotty finds a home”; “I wanna be a sailor”; and “Mutt and Jeff in westward whoa”. results.title: Cartoon connections
results.brief_description: The Simpsons and Dragon’s Lair arcade cabinets symbolise how cartoons, animation techniques and videogames have enjoyed a symbiotic relationship throughout their development.

constellations_primary.name: Cartoon classics and criticism
constellations_primary.description: A whole cavalcade of cartoons have successfully made the leap into arcades and onto consoles, but the relationship between cinema and videogames is far more likely to fizzle out.

results.description:
The Simpsons had only been on-air for one season when Konami released this side-scrolling brawler in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew how popular The Simpsons would become, they just already had the blueprints for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied almost identical mechanics, play style and combat to The Simpsons. What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions of Springfield’s favourite cartoon family, with the show’s main cast voicing the game’s characters.

Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. That’s because it was animated by Don Bluth, the legend behind The Land Before Time (1988), and its LaserDisc technology allowed for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games of the era. It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but maybe should’ve been advertised as the hardest. The timed button/stick gameplay was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.
description_for_label:

It wasn’t that Konami knew how popular The Simpsons would become, they just already had the blueprints for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied almost identical mechanics, play style and combat to The Simpsons. What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions of Springfield’s favourite cartoon family, with the show’s main cast voicing the game’s characters.

Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. That’s because it was animated by Don Bluth, the legend behind The Land Before Time (1988), and its LaserDisc technology allowed for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games of the era. It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but maybe should’ve been advertised as the hardest. The timed button/stick gameplay was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

results.title: Cartoon classics of the 30's
results.brief_description: A historic collection of classic animated cartoons from the 1930s including two very famous and much loved characters, Felix the Cat (The Goose that laid the golden egg) and Daffy Duck. Entertaining family viewing but also a fascinating look back at animation styles and techniques of the era. NB: Quality of sound and color is variable.

results.title: Carthage rediscovered
results.brief_description: Carthage was once a maritime city open to the whole of the ancient world, today it is a suburb of Tunis but one has only to dig beneath the asphalt of any part of modern Carthage, to find extensive remains of the ancient city. Several missions are today making excavations in various areas in the hope of saving the stones and the mosaics.

results.title: Cartes postales video
results.brief_description: The conventions and style of the postcard’s photographic moment are transformed by movement and sound in this exquisite collection of thirty-second video postcards. Time worn images fade in, only to be suddenly and momentarily released with a gesture, a punctuating sound - and then frozen again. Witty and often poignant, these revealing documents of time, place and memory capture a fleeting, ephemeral reality. We are invited into a narrative of what the artist calls ‘thirty seconds worth of dreams’. Produced in Paris, New York, Rome, Quebec, Iceland, Lisbon, Cairo, Algiers, and other sites around the world, these video postcards form fragments a perceptual voyage by way of the subtle magic of a temporal trompe l’oeil.

results.title: Carter's new world
results.creator_credit: Austin Hoyt, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
Jimmy Carter began his presidency with a vision of a new world of non-nuclear peace, but his dream was shattered by constant domestic and international pressures. In 1977, when he took office, Carter pledged to reduce miltary spending, pursue a foreign policy based on human rights and to negotiate arms control with the Soviet Union. By 1981, he had ordered the Senate to halt the ratification of the SALT II Treaty and the deployment of MX and Cruise Missiles. This program examines the failure of Carter’s vision and includes frank interviews with the former President, his Secretary of State, Cyrus Vance, and Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei Gromyko.

results.title: Cars
results.creator_credit: John Lasseter, Darla Anderson, Pixar Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Hotshot race car Lightning McQueen (given voice by Owen Wilson) is living life in the fast lane until he hits a detour on his way to the most important race of his life. Stranded in Radiator Springs, a forgotten town on the old Route 66, he meets Sally, Mater, Doc Hudson (Paul Newman) and a variety of quirky characters who help him discover that there’s more to life than trophies and fame. Another hit animated feature from the studios of Pixar that will delight young and young-at-heart audiences alike. Also features the voices of Cheech Marin, Tom Hanks, Billy Crystal, John Goodman and many others. Original score composed and conducted by Randy Newman.
